BC-INTERNET-PIRACY-NYT 
SOFTWARE EXECUTIVES CALL FOR BETTER ENFORCEMENT OF COPYRIGHT LAWS 

   By JERI CLAUSING   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   WASHINGTON _ If copyright laws are not more broadly and
aggressively enforced on the Internet, software developers will be
forced to resort to cumbersome technological protections that
consumers will not like, an industry leader warned Wednesday.

   ``You're going to have a piece of music that will only play on
one Walkman,'' John E. Warnock, the chairman and chief executive of
Adobe Systems, said during a panel discussion on Capitol Hill
involving 10 key software executives. ``You're going to have a
piece of software that will only work on one machine. It will
provide enormous inconvenience.''

   The industry officials were in Washington as part of an annual
lobbying trip organized by the Business Software Alliance. They
said they were not asking for new copyright laws, just better
prosecution of the fast-growing number of digital piracy cases.

   ``We need more cases brought to the court system,'' said Carol
Bartz, chairwoman and chief executive of Autodesk Inc.

   Warnock also urged the government to educate young people who
think that piracy and breaking into computers are no big deal.

   ``We would like government to set an example, to send a message
that this is breaking the law and the law will be enforced,'' he
said.

   In a survey released by the alliance in conjunction with the
visit, software executives estimated that by 2005, 66 percent of
software will be distributed over the Internet, compared with 12
percent today.

   ``The increase in Internet distribution and the growing number
of users raises the possibility of even greater losses due to
piracy in the coming years,'' said the survey, which cited an
estimate that 36 percent of all software in use last year was
pirated.

   Bartz urged Congress to encourage more copyright enforcement
efforts by federal authorities.

   In addition to meeting with administration officials and
congressional leaders over the last two days, the executives sent
letters to the major presidential candidates asking for their
dedication to three top policy goals outlined in the survey.

   In addition to broader copyright enforcement, the executives are
urging continued adoption of free-trade policies. The House
recently voted to establish free trade with China and a vote is
pending in the Senate.

   The executives are also pushing for more visas for skilled
foreign workers, saying that without more visas, 9 percent of
America's high-skilled, high-wage jobs will go unfilled.

   ``How you respond to these issues will have a vital impact on
the next phase of the Internet economy, with tremendous
consequences for American jobs, standard of living and
competitiveness,'' the executives wrote in the letters to the
candidates. ``We ask for your full support and your commitment to
make these an integral part of your policy agenda.''

   Other software executives in Washington on Wednesday were Andrew
S. Grove of Intel, Eric E. Schmidt of Novell and Stephen M. Bennett
of Intuit. Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, was in town on
Tuesday for meetings and a congressional hearing, but returned to
Seattle on Tuesday night.
